articles.title: Two States Pass Laws Allowing Some Officials to Bring Guns Inside Courthouses
articles.description: New legislation in both Arkansas and Oklahoma now allows certain individuals to carry guns into courthouses, bringing the right-to-carry debate to the front and center of the legal profession. State employees who have concealed carry permits in Arkansas are now allowed to bring their weapons into the buildings where they work at county courthouses. Similarly, the new Oklahoma law enables elected county officials to carry concealed weapons into courthouses when they are performing public duties, if they are licensed gun owners.

articles.title: Legal Sector Gains Jobs for the Third Straight Month
articles.description: In June 2017, there was an increase in jobs available in the legal services sector, according to numbers from the Labor Department’s Bureau of Labor Statistics. This makes three months in a row where such a gain has been reported. A total of 10,000 legal services jobs have been added since June 2016, bringing the most recently reported total to 1,130,800 individuals currently working in the legal services industry.

articles.title: Want to Get Email Alerts When New Legislation is Introduced by the US House and Senate? Congress.Gov Shows You How to Set It Up
articles.description: It can be challenging to keep tabs on all the legislation introduced by the US House and Senate on a day-to-day basis. This helpful Congress.gov how-to explains how to set up email alerts in four simple steps for a variety of types of legislation. It also covers how to set up filters to further personalize the alerts.

articles.title: Suit Claims Lawyer Rerouted Former Partner's Emails to Himself, Violating Electronic Privacy Law
articles.description: There are many ways information can be breached, thanks to increasing technological advancements. One recent example involves an attorney from Pennsylvania who allegedly rerouted a former law partner’s emails to himself, in violation of the federal Electronic Communications Privacy Act as well as state wiretap laws. Such laws allow individuals to file civil suits when they believe their electronic correspondence has been intercepted. If proven, damages include fines.

articles.title: Alleged Retweet by Judge Doesn't Warrant Retroactive Recusal, 9th Circuit Rules
articles.description: A federal judge’s alleged retweet of a news story about a case in which he denied a motion does not warrant his retroactive recusal, according to the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals. At issue was both the Twitter account owner’s identity and whether the tweet itself necessitated recusal. The 9th Circuit determined that recusal was unnecessary because retweeting the news story in question did not constitute plain error requiring recusal. Further, the court held that the content retweeted on that Twitter account did not amount to improper ex parte communications, regardless of whether the judge was in fact owner of the account.

articles.title: DoNotPay Legal Chatbot Now Covers 1,000 Areas of the Law and Creates Additional Chatbots for Free
articles.description: DoNotPay is a legal chatbot resource that enables drivers to challenge traffic tickets without consulting with a lawyer or hiring legal representation. Recently, it has expanded its practice areas of focus to cover almost one thousand more legal areas. Users can ask their legal questions in a chat interface, and the DoNotPay chatbot will ask a series of questions based on the legal issue they’ve indicated they need help with. From there, the bot is able to generate a letter, form, or other documentation that can be submitted to the appropriate authorities. DoNotPay’s most recent update features a service that enables anyone to create their own free legal chatbots via a submission request form. Creator Joshua Browder asserts that the bot can be used to save businesses money and improve people’s access to legal justice.

articles.title: Distance Learning Standards Under Consideration by ABA Legal Ed Section
articles.description: The ABA's Legal Education Section is considering updates to where and how accredited law schools can offer courses, as well as ways that rules currently on the books can be revised. Specifically, rules under consideration for modification include those which focus on programs that domestic law schools hold outside of the United States and those which relate to distance learning.
